hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel was fine. The room and bathroom was really small (as you would expect in Japan).Good Points - Hotel was close to subway / Swimming pool & lounge on the 11th floor, although small, was good for an hour on relatively warm afternoons / Bar was an Irish pub with the meals very good / McDonalds about a five minute walk. / Fairly quiet.Bad Points - Thought I'd bought breakfast but on first morning, realised I hadn't / Check in at 3pm was a bit negative (I'd flown almost 14 hours and got to the hotel at 12pm the following morning). Went to lunch but still really negative.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Yes this was a great find. Great price for Tokoyo for new modern hotel. Just 20 mins walk west of the main Shinjuku train station or just 2 stops on the Odieo line E27 to E29 . Use the stop numbers is the best way !We popped up at the A2 exit at Nishishinjukku and bang there was the hotel . 1 minute walk.The was small but very practical and all the necessary room facilities. No problem for the two of us. Very comfortable and quiet. Very clean.The Irish pub downstairs offers a fantastic full breakfast . The best value breakfast I can remember in a long time. Definitely a nightlight and worth eating your full before a big day of touring. 10/10. Just 1500 yen for all you can eat . Quality!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Location - 1 stop away from shinjuku. Less busy part of town.Restaurants- quite a few choices on the same street including access to family mart and Lawson across the hotelRooms - Basic but small rooms. Good for 1 person. Seems to be the standard in Japan. Pillows were odd, like cardboard stuck together, good thing I had a travel pillow!Bathrooms- Very clean!Check-in - automated and easy Over-all: will definitely stay again!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: A very busy hotel with 18 floors and only 4 lifts and no stairs. Around checkout time we waited 6 times for the lift and every time the door opened it was packed to the brim full of people. With the coronavirus a serious threat forcing that amount of strangers in a lift together for a 10am check out time is irresponsible. The same thing happened the night before it was the exact same thing waiting 10-15 mins for the lift. Ridiculous. Rooms were tiny as was the bathroom. On the plus side the TV was big and there was a nice view from the window. The male staff members were very nice, polite and accommodating.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: A well know chain hotel in Japan. Room were very minuscule, but, clean. Disappointed part was the room AC was centralised. The hotel expects guests to open the window and sleep. Facilities such as the pool was also closed during winter. Is included in my room tariff yet I couldn’t use. The vicinity was great with few convenience stores and some other eateries located. 24hrs Macdonald’s is also very close by. It’s accessible by foot to Shinjuku Station whereby all the shopping district is situated.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We stayed for several days and had a great experience with this hotel. The staff was very accommodating with holding our luggage on arrival and departure. The rooms were very clean and cleaned every day. Water pressure is excellent and hot. Room was quiet--I never heard any noise from other guests. The bed is very comfortable.However, the room is very very small. It was a challenge to move around with the luggage on the first day, but you get into a routine that works.You will not get any AC during the winter. If the room is hot, then we just turned off the HVAC with the unit on the bed and opened the window till the room cooled down. After that, it was great.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Well I have stayed at a lot of hotels around the world but this hotel room was the smallest by far but I believe it was to Japanese standards, The room was well equiped and very clean and modern but super small. Passing each other in the room was very friendly!! The other thing we found strange were the pillows which were firm but only about 5cm or 2 inches deep which made for a restless night, The other strange feature was that there is heating only and no Cooling AC although the room has a strange box which acts as a fan, If the room is hot then you open the window. Staff were helpful but could not speak English so all communication was done with the aid of a PC If you are looking for just a place to stay well this is fine but if you require some room to move then this is not for you

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I arrived at 7am on an overnight flight from Hong kong hoping they could check me in asap. They told me at 12, so I left for breakfast and for a walk in the area because the lobby doesn't even have a socket where you can charge your phone or computer. Not even a trush can. At 12 they told me if I wanted an "early check in" ( what??? early check in???, is 12pm!!! ) I had to pay 3000Y, about 26€. I told that girl the front desk guy in the morning didn't mention they will charge me, just that my room would be ready at 12pm. That girl, Ms. Hongo, treated me like a piece of xxx: she just say PAY. Not even an explanation or anything, I told her I wanted to talk to the manager because of her behaviour, no maners to treat a customer, she said the manager wasm't available. I told her to leave a message to the manager because I wanted to talk to him about her. The manager never contacted me. I left the bext day paying, no chance to complain and neither Ms. Hongo or her manager care at all. I will never go back to that Hotel chain in my life!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Let me begin by saying I'm not one of those travelers who expects huge "American style" accommodations in other countries. I read the other reviews and expected the rooms to be small, but nothing could prepare me for what I got! This was nothing less than bait-and-switch since the photos on their site are NOTHING like the actual rooms.First of all, the hotel is filled with millennials and thanks to the paper-thin walls, you have the pleasure of hearing them yell in the hallways and come into their rooms, slamming doors, drunk at all hours thanks to the "pub" on the first floor. This made me feel like I was staying in a youth hostel or frat house. When I first got into my room, I realized nothing was plugged in (an effort to save on the cost of electricity). This was my first clue that when it comes to saving a penny, this hotel will do it! After plugging in my temperature control, I turned up the thermostat to warm the freezing cold room but little happened. I went to the desk and asked if my heater was broken. I was then told that all of the rooms in the hotel are kept at the same temperature controlled at the front desk! You can not change the temperature of your own room! It's cold during the day (the bathroom has no heat at all and a direct vent to the outside which makes it downright freezing) and it's HOT at night. I actually slept with the window open in January in order to sleep - however, then you get to put up with the street noise. Also, everything you've turned on, including your air purifying system will turn off as soon as you remove your key and leave your room, so each time you enter the room, you have to turn everything on again.The room itself is tiny and the bathroom is minuscule! There are no dressers or drawers of any kind - and the "closet" consists of two pegs hanging on the wall with four broken hangers on them. There is an "ice engine" only on the 2nd floor, but no ice bucket in the room. The bed was so old it literally slanted on one side so badly I had to sleep against the wall to prevent falling out during the night and the pillows are 2 inches thick and hard as rocks. They offer "English breakfast" for 15,000 yen IF you pay in advance - if you don't it's more expensive. Their idea of English breakfast is a hot dog bar and chicken nuggets. They also offer scrambled eggs the consistency of thin soup.Perhaps the worst part of the experience was the "housekeeping". There were short, black hairs on my pillow when I checked in. I shook off the pillow and used the other one assuming they would be changed in the morning. The following day I noticed that none of the bedding was changed. That night I purposely left a small lipstick stain on one of the pillows to see if it would get changed the next day. The next day after housekeeping finished my room, I looked at the pillow. They actually turned the pillowcase inside out and reused it! The final insult came when I asked the front desk to call a taxi for the following morning and was told they had already used up their quota of taxi calls and refused to call one! Four days later on the final morning, I asked again for the desk to call a cab and was told there would be a 5000 yen charge to make the call. I ended up hailing a cab from the street.The bottom line is this hotel is a reasonable price for Tokyo, but you get bargain basement treatment, service, accommodations and you'll get nickeled and dimed at every turn. Truly the worst hotel I have ever stayed in anywhere.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: My partner, family and friends (6 in total) stayed here on our last night in Tokyo. It wasnt as central in Shinju-ku as our previous stay, but I enjoyed being away from the city center. SPA:* I did not use the spa, but I do want to mention that these are gender separated and have rules posted near the entrance. * One of the rules is to not have any tattoos. The spa/bath is meant to be nude, so there is really no hiding. Please do not be disrespectful of Japanese culture and the rules to this hotel. Location: * Right across the street from the subway* 7/11 across the street* Cute coffee shop half a block down* Fair amount of diverse restaurants within a five block radiusHotel: * Elegant entrance* Tablet based checkin/out (Very easy to use and offers multiple languages) and supported by staff * Complimentary bottled sweet coffee for check-in* Strict check-in time (hard to check in earlier) * English speaking staff ** Room ** Very small, but that is by design. The room fit one full size bed (fitting from wall to wall) and a mounted TV. ** Rooms were small enough that the service was unable to clean one of our rooms due to 3 weeks of travel luggage (no compliant here, just giving you an idea of room size)** Bathroom is small. If you are over 6ft, my guess is your knees would touch the bathroom door when you sit on the toilet** Shower has good (hot) water pressureAmenities: * Bathroom amenities were great! Down to a comb, hair ties, toothbrush and toothpaste, shower cap etc* 24/hr Coin Operated laundry on the second floor (decently priced)* Pub downstairs with an English Breakfast (didnt visit)* Room TV has a custom home screen to help navigate. You can change to various languages. Movie selection is eh and didnt find much on-air channels. * Room TV also gives an idea of the wait time/occupancy capacity of the Baths (Spa) and allows you to extend your checkout (per hour)

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: MY wife and I spent 4 nights here. The room was clean and new. A few things we didnt like was that there is a pub downstairs, so its always pretty chaotic down stairs, the pillows are terrible!!!! I read this before I went on reviews and thought those people were just complainers, THEY ARE NOT COMPLAINERS! I did not mind location, but it is about 30 min walk to the JR station, my wife and I like to walk so it was not bad, but if you do not like to walk, this spot is not for you.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: LOCATIONit’s very convenient, when you exit at a2 you see the hotel diagonally across. lots of convenient stores, restaurants and local japanese pharmacy (tomods).it’s located in the toei oedo (pink line) nishi shinjuku GOCHOME (which is a different station from nishi shinjuku).while it is just across the subway i find it annoying i had to switch trains to major stations i.e. shibuya, ginza, tokyo station. ONSENi love onsens. the onsen area is quite spacious. there is an indoor and outdoor onsen. i don’t see the point of going to the outdoor onsen if snow isn’t falling as there is no view to see.ROOMsmall, which was expected. bed was raised up so you can put stuff under.AIRCONDITIONINGmy sister asked for ac and they said they couldn’t do anything as it’s heater time.CHECK IN AND STAFFwe arrived around 2pm and went through the process of check-in without getting the rooms. my sister and bro in law arrived earlier and got their luggages and room key. when it was my time a trainee was helping me and i had to re-check-in. we were asked to type data (built in tablet like computer which kept on typing each letters twice that made it annoying) which took forever.to be fair it was a trainee and she was gracious.but i echo the sentiments of the reviewers that the staff are inefficient and not that hospitable.the key they gave us couldn’t unlock the door and my other sister asked them to come up as we were very tired and was late at night. they said we had to go down.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The location is perfect for my trip as I plan to go to Mitaka, Gajoen Hotel, Ghibli Museum and also to the other side Akihabara, Odaiba, Maihama for Disney Sea.. train station exit is so nearby makes it convenient for me. Family Mart and Lawson store also just walking distance for food/snack stocking. Few nice cafes around and the best part is that its not dizzily busy like other places in Tokyo.. definitely will choose this hotel again when im visiting tokyo again oh and they hv their own sento (bathhouse) for guests.. PERFECT!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We came for 4 nights. After 2 weeks of traveling in Japan, and this was the worst!!!! 1. The hotel is not in a central place. There are much better neighborhoods to be in while in Tokyo. There is a metro station near the hotel, but you are better off staying at a central location.2. The real problem of this hotel is the staff. If I could grade a 0... I would! Staff at the reception that could not care less. The give you a feeling you are bothering them. They are so helpless and with no motivation. A few examples:*We arrived at the hotel and asked if our suitcases arrived. We sent them a few days before. The receptionist said no. We asked him to please check. He said he knows and it did not arrive. After 10 minutes he went to check and found them. We almost had a heart attack. *we entered the room and saw the pillows were like a piece of cardboard. We asked for another pillow. The answer we got was unbelievable: put a towel on your pillow.*we asked to reserve a cab for the next morning. The answer we got was: we can't. Why? Because they work with one station and they are out of cabs. The solution, go out and find a cab on your own* Whenever I asked for the manager, they gave a few versions: there is no manager for the next few days, or... every receptionist is the manager. I have a few names, and they all were managers even though it was clear they certainly were not.Conclusion: the human resource which is supposed to give you a good welcomed feeling does exactly the opposite here. They give you a bad feeling, a very unwelcomed feeling, and if you add this to the unattractive location, you understand that this is not a recommended hotel. I think it is a shame no one really manages this hotel, and that the service is unacceptable. When you pay... you expect... and this hotel does not deliver. Very disappointed. Will not come here again.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Did extensive searches before booking 3 different hotels for our 2 week stay in Tokyo. I initially made the mistake of focusing only on hotels immediately next to or located to the east side of Shinjuku where are the actions are. This particular APA hotel is slightly out of the way & on the quieter side (west) of Shinjuku, 2 stops away on the Oedo line. Location was still great, the subway stop (exit 2) is literally right across from the hotel. Exit 1 is prob 200 feet further away but it has elevator for those with heavy dunnage, also it’s on the same side of the street as the hotel.Room was very small as expected, no where to put my suitcase. The bathroom was tiny, small basin with minimal cupboard space. They have a single complicated system that uses levers, knobs & dials to control the water for both the shower as well as the basin. One wrong move and the shower might be spraying hot water in your face when you are expecting cool water gently coming out of the basin faucet. This was consistent with other APA hotels in the area. I only used the shower once, the temp & pressures were very good. Mostly I took advantage of the in-house Onsen facilities, going twice daily to soak & relax. The bed was firm, pillows were firm, if you are a back sleeper who usually keep your head straight up you will be fine. The moment you tilt your head slightly to either side you will notice the lack of support that you would expect from a regular fluffy pillow. In terms of amenities I liked the mini fridge, hairdryer a new set of Japanese bathrobe each day for the spa. On the other hand none of the APA hotels have safety boxes in the room. The Onsen spa was quite nice, theirs is a bit more spacious than the other APA which I will review later. Indoor as well as outdoor open air pools are available. I prefer the latter as I like fresh cool air while getting cooked. There are also 2 large earthenware tubs (shawagara?) outside for individual bathers, note that the temperature in those tubs are much higher so ease yourself in gently. The pools here are more spacious than the other APA I stayed at & the whole facility is very nice. No tattooed bathers are allowed, but 1 nite I saw 3 guys with extensive tats on their arms & backs came in. They were mean looking & were probably yakuza members. Two of them were even making loud yelling noises as if other guests did not even existed. Not sure if the hotel staff ever checked. Tried their BF buffet once just to see and it was ok. Selection was limited compared to the bigger hotels. Coffee was very good even though it was dispensed from an ancient coffee maker & cheap self-pouring pot. I am used to nice hotels with fancy coffee makers & dispensers. Other than BF I never tried the Irish pub. They don’t show any American sports, I asked but unfortunately no NFL games. Nearby several convenience stores, McDonalds 5 min walk away. There were some good looking restaurants in the area but I did not try. On the other hand I enjoyed eating a few times in 24-hr casual diner (Matsuya), good & cheap. Hotel Staff overall were efficient & helpful, adequate English skills. Note they charge you 420 JPY to help you get taxi service. After staying in other hotels in the area I have come to appreciate this place a bit more for its quiet & convenient location, as well as good quality spa facilities. It was also better value than other comparable hotels, perhaps on the map it has the illusion of being further away than it actually is. I would def consider staying here again.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I was pleased with this hotel. The check-in was very smooth, and the room was clean with a great view. The spa was well managed, but very busy for the ladies. The location was across the street from a train station, making getting to and from sites is very convenient. I only have a few small complaints; the laundry machines were always in use and the pillows were flat and hard. All in all, we enjoyed our stay.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: This hotel was recommended to us. We arrived from the airport and check-in was very easy. Had prepaid on Expedia so made it easier. Room was very nice. It's Japan, so the rooms are small. But spotless and well equipped - including the world's largest television. Bathroom is immaculate and very small. Western style beds were very comfortable. Location is excellent. Across the street from the subway, and a lovely walking area. Extremely good coffee shop on the same side of the street about a block away. Excellent noodle shops down the alley. Overall great spot and good hotel in the large hotel category.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel has a pretty good location, a few stops from Shinjuku which has the busiest, most complex train station I've ever been in. Check in to the hotel was quick and efficient, thankfully after along day getting there and a welcoming beer in the reasonably priced Irish bar helped enormously. The hotel room that we had was pretty small, but we were seldom in the room, so it didn't matter that much. There are no wardrobes in the rooms, but there are a few hangers so you can hang some clothes up, storage for your suitcase would be under the bed. There are other amenities in the hotel on the second floor (pool) but never used them, but they do seem to get a decent report. Metro was just across the road, so access to transport very good. All in all, its a good hotel, in a good spot.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: You're paying for the location - thats it! The rooms are the same everywhere - small but practical. What else does a traveller need? The location is good and easy to navigate in such a huge city! Clean rooms & bathroom; Good cleaning practice - you leave the badge outside, the team does their job without skipping. Would stay again - it was really good value for money (considering the hotel range and the location). *** Very long queue for the check in... never ending. The ladies pool was always busy (as per the intercom messages on the hotel' TV system). Didn't take the breakfast - can't imagine how crowded it was!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: My husband and I booked this hotel for 10 nights in September. Just to begin, September is very hot and humid with bouts of rain since it is the beginning of typhoon season. With that being said, I am already pleased with this hotel and the APA chain. The facility is kept very clean and cool with the hot weather. Most of the staff speak English. We arrived many hours before the 1500 (3 pm) check in and we were able to store our luggage in the lobby until it was check in time. This enabled us to walk around the hotel and its vicinity.Staff:All employees at this facility were excellent. From the front desk to housekeeping. Very professional and informative. Room:The size of the room is small. Yes, however, you are not coming to Japan to stay in a room and order room service. If you want that, please go to the larger hotels (Hilton, Hyatt, etc.) for those amenities. Our room was set at 18°C every night and we never had any issues with the air conditioning. Also, with the severe humidity, there is a dehumidifier in each room to help with that. There are no closets so all luggages are to be pushed under the bed. There are plenty of AC plugs for all of your electronics as well as 1 dedicated area for a USB plug. Don't forget your travel convertors. Each room has a small water boiler, coffee, creamer, sugar, and green tea. Room/public bath robes are also provided and changed daily. There is a small refrigerator under the desk. There is a nice big tv in every room. The Wi-Fi in the room and the main lobby is very quick.Bed:We got a double room. Just to caveat this, I am 5'8" and my husband is 6'3" athletic build. The bed was just right for us, but since I'm used to a king size, I felt it was a bit tight. Mattress was comfortable. The pillows were soft, but if you like thick fluffy pillows, I suggest bringing your own to supplement the hotels.Bathroom:Leave your shampoo, conditioner, and body wash at home...unless you only use certain ones. They have large bottles of each so there won't be any chance you'll run out. Also, every room has a razor, toothbrush/toothpaste, shower cap, hair tie, q-tip, body scrubber, and travel comb/brush. Towels are changed daily. What I love about Japan are the bidets. The only thing missing is the dryer part of the bidet but if you've never tried it, now is your chance. Pool/Public Bath:I cannot comment on the pool since I did not see it. The hotel offers a public bath for men and women separately. Each public bath has an indoor and an outdoor section. For many travelers who walked as much as my husband and I did, the public bath was a wonderful way to relax. Due to it being separate, it was hard to sit alone in the public bath without having anyone to talk to. Please be respectful to all the hotel patrons as this is a naked public bath. Wash your hair and body with shampoo and soap before entering. The female "locker room" is equipped with hair dryers, face wash, face softener, and lotion for post public bath needs.Laundry:Again, September is hot and humid which means your clothes will be damp from the sweat. Laundry is available for use. In 10 nights, we did laundry twice. What a difference that makes. 500¥ for the wash and 100¥ for 30 min dry. Restaurant:We did not purchase the breakfast option but we did eat at the restaurant that is connected to the lobby. Irish Pub themed with good food. The steak and fries was a good size and a good deal. I definitely wouldn't mind having that steak as I write this review.Location:The hotel is literally a 1 minute walk from the Toei Ōedo Subway line. E29 Nishi-shinjuku-gochome is the stop. If you need to go to Shinjuku station, you can take the subway or you can walk about 10-15 minutes and you can get to the west entrance of Shinjuku station where the JR train is. There are quite a few places to eat around this hotel, but if you want to be in the center of everything, this place me be too quiet. There is a Lawson and FamilyMart within walking distance as well. Overall:Great location. Great price. Great facility. Definitely will come back.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I had booked this hotel, as with a hotel in Kyoto and a later hotel in Tokyo, via BookAAHotels.com, and chose it due to a combination of a reasonable nightly rate and a generous offer of American Airlines AAdvantage miles coming back to me in return. Especially within these parameters, it well-served my needs in Tokyo, as a rather new hotel with a decent (if small) room and very close proximity to a subway station. The hotel does not have a concierge, which is no big deal, but I found the front desk clerks only blandly efficient. No particularly friendliness and few spoke much English, unable to recommend any restaurants or give guidance about getting to Mount Fuji. Of course, I don't speak any Japanese, so I don't mean this to be highly critical, just advisory. A bit interestingly, the hotel's restaurant is an Irish Pub, which made for decent late night snacking, but I didn't feel the amount charged for the breakfast buffet was worth my partaking. And I thought charging 1000 Yen (roughly $10 USD) to use the swimming pool for an hour was pretty chintzy, especially as I had prepaid for 8 nights at the hotel. Seems the fee could've been waived for a time or two in the pool, but no.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I was hesitant to book as I had read quite a few negative reviews. But my daughter and I loved the hotel photos so I booked and I’m very glad I did. We have had a great experience here. The hotel is stunning, our room stunning (small as is the norm in Japan), Ice cold air con (control is located on the bed head). Grreat breakfast (we pre paid). We booked a room with view and it did not disappoint (ask for room 2003). Unlimited movie viewing for $10 over a 24 hour period (they could do with a few more english movie options). They have both a men and womens day spa and a beautiful swimming pool. Daily housekeeping with complimentary toothbrushes and other useful little products is a nice touch. Vending machines within hotel include soft drink and alcohol. The bar downstairs offers meals too and has a pool table. The coin operated laundry needs a few more washers and dryers as there are only 2 of each to service all of the guests. I have stayed at much more expensive higher rated hotels that were absolute dumps in comparison to this stunning hotel. This hotel gets 5 star review from me and I think it is as good as a 4 star hotel and the interior decorating is that of a 5 star hotel. Beautiful decadent interior decoration.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Room was very neat, its small like a cruise cabin. can't complain on amenities. People were very helpful. Felt little hard to communicate since not all them understand English. Subway/Metro station was really close by (walk able distance). There are many groceries stores next to the hotel. Beautiful location. We were able to walk to Tokyo Metropolitan Government Building.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Be aware that if you arrive before the 3 pm check in time, they actually make you wait till 3 pm unless you pay 1000yen per hour extra. This is not apparent on the booking site. Not a great start to a stay.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Room was tiny for 2 people with 2 medium sized luggages. Bathroom was even tinier but clean. If you just need a decent place to sleep and bathe, this is good enough.Hotel is near the train station - about 2 min walk from Nishi-Shinjuku-Gochome Station (Oedo Line), which is 2 stops away from Shinjuku Station (Yamanote Line). Shinjuku Station is about 10 mins away via taxi. There’s a Lawson, Family Mart and a grocery nearby.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed here for 3 nights, with no real complaints. It’s a big, busy, corporate business style hotel, so don’t expect anything particularly unique. Tiny room, but with everything you need. Bed was comfy, but pillows were tiny and hard. Right across the street from the subway and 2 stops away from Shinjuku station. Not much in the area in terms of food etc, but short hop on the subway and you’re sorted. Overall, I wouldn’t pick this place again, but if you just need a cheapish base to explore Tokyo, this hits the spot.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Our double room was quite spacious and bath was big also compared to the various places I've stayed in Japan. We weren't able to checkin early. The hotel is across the road from the subway, plenty of Family Mart, Lawson and 7/11 down the road.15minute walk to shinjuku station.I loved the public onsen bath. The pool was small. I would totally recommend this place if you want to base at Shinjuku.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed here x4nights in a twin room (x2 single beds). The major positive is that is in a good easily accessible location. Subway (Oedo line) is on the doorstep (across the road) and there are a number of nearby attractions within walking distance (Tokyo Metropolitan Government Buildings Observatories - definitely go there, Shinjuku Chuo Park and some small temples dotted near).Couple of negatives that others have stated in their reviews that I reinforce:1 - The rooms are indeed small, although it was useful that the beds have storage space underneath.2 - There is absolutely no leeway in checking in earlier than 3pm unless you pay extra. We arrived 2:30pm after a long flight and journey from Narita airport to the hotel, we were told our room was ready but couldn't be checked in until 3pm, thought there would be some leeway but reception staff were fierce in stating 'No!'3 - Breakfast was OK with both western and Japanese buffet options but basic.Overall value for money but we wished we had paid a little extra for a bit better elsewhere I am afraid.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Booked this hotel due to it's good location to the city. Check in was easy, and we opted in for 1,000 yen one hour early check in. Although the room was small, it had everything we needed for the week we were there. The hotel had a swimming pool which was cold, although the area was nice at the end of the night to chill out. There was also an Onsen which was amazing! - Staff were friendly and of course efficient, and luggage storage in the lobby was available free of charge on check out.Less than a 10 second walk from the hotel is a Subway line, and the area had plenty of places to eat / drink as well as 7/11 and Family Mart. At the end of the street is a nice park, which is nice to walk around on a morning. Fully recommended!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I got a city view room and the size was perfectly fine for 1 person. I arrived at 11:00 and was allowed to check in at noon but for an extra fee (check in time is at 3:00pm). Staff were very friendly. Most importantly the rooms were clean and I got two new bottles of water each day and towels were changed. Location is two subway stops from Shinjuku Station. I relied on the Oedo line of the Tokyo subway to take me to Shinjuku Station in 5 min from where I changed to the JR lines. It is a bit of walk to change between lines but hardly an issue once you find the way once. I realized it was actually better I stayed a bit away from Shinjuku Station as the hotel’s neighborhood was nice, safe and quiet. Plenty of convenience stores nearby as well as a 24hour McDonald’s. I had breakfast at the plethora of coffee shops nearby. For some places like Shibuya, Roppongi, you can just bypass shinjuku and take the subway directly.In addition, there were plenty of cabs in both late hours of night and early hours of the morning around the hotel. Coin operated laundry service was available as well.On the whole the hotel was perfect value for my 4 day stay in Tokyo and there was nothing to complain about.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Really, really, really small space. Think c!oset. Do feel bad for the partner (me) who sleeps on the left-side of the bed because there is no access. You have to climb over your bedmate (literally) to get to your side of the bed! For a wine corkscrew, I had to go down to the front desk and "sign" before they'd release it! (You see, we can't trust those lawless wine-drinkers to return it)And that 3pm check-in? It's a scam! They hold onto that til the absolute last minute......Oh, they have rooms available, but they (nastily) charge Y1000 yen for each hour you want in early. (Our friends paid Y3000 extra to get a room key at 12pm, cuz his partner was ill, and needed to get him to bed). Overall, I find this place user unfriendly.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: They doubled charged us, the rooms are like jail cells in the desert. It might have been a language barrier but they gave us incorrect information. We told them our corner room was a sauna and they fixed it for a couple hours then it was back to unbearable, they control it from the front desk! The rooms are not big enough for 2 people and suitcases.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Our room was bought 1 week before we flew so I guessed all the other more spacious rooms were snapped up. Room had very little walking space and toilet was very narrow but do-able.Hotel is literally 1 min walk away from the metro underpass at Nishi-Shinjuku Gochome station, which is accessible by lift. Station is 2 stops away from Shinjuku terminal which connects to several other subway/metro lines, trains & buses. There is also a JR East office there where tourists can exchange for their JR Passes and book their shinkansen.Hotel's breakfast was comfortable & sufficient enough.There are several restaurants & I saw 1 where you can select from a variety of dishes to make your own bento set. Our favourite was Coco-Ichibanya which opens till 12 am. 24-hour Lawsons & Family Mart for whatever else we might need too.There's a separated female & male onsen in the hotel, indoor & outdoor which I went to take a look but did not try & it looked really good. There is coin laundry (JPY300 for 30 min) & dryer (JPY100 for 30min).Movies on Demand can be bought for JPY1000 for 1 day.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed here for 3 nights and it was absolutely amazing for the price we paid. The hotel had a lot of amenities such as spas, pool, their own restaurant and many more. We had breakfast included in our package and it was very delightful and enjoyable.Close to the subway and it is 2 stops away from Shinjuku which was very convenient.Hotel staff were very efficient in getting us checked in and providing information on recommendations and how to get to places.Hotel rooms are not too spacious but your essentials are there. Managed to have 2 suitcases in the room opened and still have room to walk around.I would 100% go back if I were staying in a hotel in Tokyo and had a medium budget.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We had a lovely stay. The room, as all over the country, was quite small but cozy and all the service were nice, breakfast included. The subway station is really 2 minutes by walk and in 20 min by walk you can reach Shinjuku station.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The room is just big enough to fit the bed. It took almost an hour to get checked in, and everything they offer costs money. It’s way to expensive for what it is. I really don’t recommend, you can get a nice bed and breakfast for half the price

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Once we had got over the size of the room (very small) this hotel was excellent in every way - location to train, walking distance to Shinjuku, nice area, clean, room well adapted for conveniences, quiet and decent breakfast. Cost for our 7 night stay was reasonable for a good city location.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Service was very good. Staff were so helpful.Room was small and tight for 2 persons, hard to get in bedClean, comfortable bed, need extra pillowsLocation is excellent, very near the subway for commuting Amenities were more than enough

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We stayed here for Tokyo marathon. It’s across the street from metro stop so easy access. Also within walking distance to start of race. Rooms were very small but served its purpose. Rooms clean. Robes provided for spa.
user_name:
wohlrabj
Washington DC, District of Columbia

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Check in was pretty smooth and was allowed to check in before the allowed checkin time but need to pay 1000yen extra for each hour. So ended up by paying 3000yen for being able to access my room three hours before the regular checkin time. After a 18 hours travel I was exhausted so I really needed my room fast.The room is extremely small and narrow with absolutely no view at all. But everything is clean.If you have a tattoo, please do not try to access the hotel SPA. The hotel categorizes people with tattoo to be a part of organzied crime and will kick you out if you try to enter.Myself have a tattoo and feel it is very disrespectful and impolite to be treated as a criminal just for the reason to have a tattoo.For that reason aline I will never stay in this hotel again.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: How long do you really stay in the room? It's 30 directly opposite a metro line, which will have you into the main areas from 5 min to 20 min. Very easy access!! The room are small but have everything you need ! If you don't smoke ensure you ask for a non smoking room. I didn't and it stank!! Pillows are tiny and rock hard, I strongly slept well on them! Check in is very struck not before 1500, you can obviously leave your bags before hand and go out and explore. The check in is done on computer screen, it was self explanatory, the reception man went to get my bag and I had completed it and had my key! Cool it all happens through the machine! Rooms have a kettle and fridge. You can hire a trouser press if you want. Check out.. drop the key in the box and you are away. The only thing I didn't like was Break fast started at 0700, so I missed it each day as I had to leave before that. The Irish bar, does not have table service even for food maintain cheapens the hotel slightly and strict on ordering on the right, pick up on the left. Would I stay again yes as a solo or business traveller. Not with a family.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Very good experience, definitely good value for money, great views from the hotel room... I think we had everything we needed and the room was nice, cozy and clean. Little the room was, but it didn't matter (there was two of us), liked it.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Hotel is 1min walk from subway shinjuku gochomae, lots of restaurant and convience store around. But not near JR or any main station, so it's a little out of the way.Don't feel welcomed when we were asked to do our own self check in and staffs were not friendly.Room is extremely small, smallest of all the Japan hotel i've stayed.We asked for some information on places. The staff was eager to end the conversation and reluctantly "assisted" us. Probably the worst customer service i've encountered in Japan.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Staff on the front desk and information desk were unhelpful, rude, non-responsive. They even chatted amongst themselves and looked at us and giggled. Staying here completely ruined my last few days in Japan. Avoid this hotel if you’re looking for friendly, helpful service or any service for that matter.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Pricing was good size was typical of an APA hotel. Unfortunately you get those horrible little pillows that are spa standard. Tv was an awesome size but not much to chose from to watch. Staff were friendly enough.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I never write reviews but I honestly felt compelled to write this review. A little background about me. I’m from Las Vegas, Nevada. We are known for our hotels and hospitality industry because that’s primarily what our city is. I booked a 2 week stay at this hotel. It’s in a very convenient area close to Harajuku and Shinjuku. My room was very cramped and located on the smoking floor. Prior to checking in I missed my flight for the prior day and it was booked when I arrived at the hotel and told them they did not refund me for the day missed due to circumstances not of my own nor did they offer to upgrade my room. NO ONE IN THIS HOTEL SPEAKS ANY ENGLISH, so it was nearly impossible to communicate with anyone. ( in Vegas a large percentage of our hotel employees are bilingual and if they are not they go out of their way to find a translator not ignore your questions or request as they did in this hotel) they do not accommodate people with tattoos in their onsens which is understandable but quite a bummer because they have so many younger people in and out of this hotel. There is no gym facilities. There is a restaurant located downstairs that is attached to the hotel not sure if it’s owned by the hotel but horrible service. Every time I ate there whatever I wanted was sold out or not available a good 80% of the time it was closed. If I asked for utensils or condiments I was told no. I was pushed out of my room with a phone call from the lobby telling me they needed to change my sheets after I clearly had a do not disturb sign on the door when I told them politely please come after 3 they told me no it was too late and that why would come at 2( why would you change my sheets the day before I check out? I’ve been here 2 weeks and haven’t had an issue with them changing the sheets because they only changed them once prior because I took off the sheets MYSELF, I found this extremely inconsiderate to the fact that My needs need to be met as I am a paying customer yet it was the opposite.I guess my expectations were high for this hotel because it was beautiful when I walked in the lobby but I was sadly mistaken. I will not ever return or book with this company nor its sister companies. I wish they would have made the experience in this hotel a better one.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We stayed at this hotel for 2 nights and will NEVER stay at an APA hotel again. We were in room 407 at this hotel and unfortunately we couldn't open our bags in our room - it was too small. We had to take them out to the hallway to pack and unpack. I've stayed in many hotels in Japan and this one is by far the smallest. This room should not be classed as double room - it should only have one single bed in it. There were many problems with our stay. Firstly, the base of the bed was too small for the mattress which meant the bed had a lean on it. The pillows were like rocks. When my partner went to the toilet he had to leave the door open because his legs didn't fit inside the toilet area. We had to pay extra money to access the hotel's pool etc . We were on a non-smoking floor, yet the place stunk of smoke. The breakfast on offer downstairs was average. After our two nights stay all we could do was laugh and learn by our mistakes. Hopefully reader, you can learn by our mistake - don't stay here. Try somewhere in Ikebukuru where you find something bigger, friendlier and cheaper.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Self check-in and check out hotel. I didn't like this as this takes away the human connection. Also, although clean, the rooms are very small. If you are getting the single room it is really good for one person. I am used to big rooms. No air conditioning is available as this is managed by the hotel centrally. They do have heater though. What made the difference was the hotel service. I wanted to change from a smoking to a non-smoking room. As I made the change I forgot my valuables in the room that I left. The personnel reacted immediately and contacted me as I was coming back by the end of the day. Everything was there.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: A nice hotel with small but comfortable rooms and perfect location. However, the reception staff are not friendly. The auto-checking is a total disaster and you waste a lot of time trying to do your own check-in. Finally the staff has to help you always without a smile.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel is located less than a minutes walk from Nishi-Shinjuku Go-chome station - this is very convenient.Upon arrival the staff were very helpful but for the sake of honesty I will say that the checking in process was made way too complicated with their machines. In my view, we could have checked in within less than a minute if we simply did it one-to-one with a person, however we were made to use these machines which made everything more difficult and took almost 10 minutes to navigate.Once in the room however, all was forgiven. It is a business-style hotel so the rooms are small and there are no frills or luxuries, but it is very comfortable. In particular, I enjoyed the huge size of the TV! If you get an upper floor room the views of Shinjuku are spectacular!You are in walking distance of many restaurants and bars, and even the centre of Shinjuku is not too far away. We didn't try to breakfast on site but instead went for a coffee on the corner (Counterpart Coffee Gallery) - my advise is to avoid this coffee shop as it takes literally 20 minutes to make you a very mediocre coffee... But back to the hotel, I will definitely be staying here again as it was a comfortable and affordable stay, in a brilliant location (especially when comparing to more luxury hotels such as the Hilton or the Park Hyatt, I would definitely opt instead for the simplicity and affordability of APA).

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: State there for two nights. The first night was mean mostly, however, when we returned and rechecked in for our second night of stay, that was the beginning of a nightmare. We simply couldn't feel any hospitality from the front desk staff (中本) who assisted us with check in. He was giving us a really bad attitude for no reason. For instance, we would ask him questions and he would act like as if he couldn't hear. Even though if we follow up with our questions, he has no initiative or intention to assist us or answer our enquiries. Our experience was so bad that we have decided never again to stay with this hotel in the future because we don't think this is how a customer or anyone should be treated. We will also spread out the words to our family and friends so they won't have to be victims of such unacceptable service.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed in Dec 2018, the location is ok but not that central. The rooms are tiny with small beds, we had a problem with the heating as it stayed on all night and we couldn't turn it off. I woke up at one point and it was 29°C, when we went to reception to ask for help we were completely and rudely shut down before even finishing the sentence. It's obviously a reoccurring problem for the hotel. We were told it's winter in Japan (about 8°C) and there's only heat no air conditioning, followed by 'open the window' several times when trying to ask for a fan. Opening the window is not helpful, obviously I already tried that however the room is so small you end up with hot air blowing on one side and cold air on the other. Pillows are unusually flat, only 2 are provided when 4 is needed. My main complaint was the staff being rude when we were simply and politely asking how to use air conditioning.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The room was lovely, but small. We stayed there for a week with two of staying and the space to get ready in was pretty tight, and there wasn’t much room to store or take anything out of your suitcase, however it was a bargain stay compared to other places we looked at.We’d read dubious reviews on Shinjuku, however we had no problems at all. There were small supermarkets and a 7/11 to get drinks and snacks from which kept it cheap and it was about a 20 min walk to the main Shinjuku station (we had a JR rail pass, so generally didn’t have to buy extra tickets once we got there, although even when we did it was pretty cheap). If you have bags, there is a station right across from in (Shinjuku gochome (or something like that)), which was really handy. Whilst we were here we went to Disneyland, this took us about an 1hr 20mins door-to-door (with 3 train changes). There was a fair amount of walking in stations, but do-able.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel is right opposite the metro station. The rooms are very very small but thats how tokyo is. Rather go for the bigger rooms which are on the higher floors. It doesnt have room service but the restaurant on the ground floor is amazing.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: A nice hotel, Check in and check out are DIY (do it yourself), but there's a hotel staff to help you also.Location is not really perfect, but it is accessible via subway.Tried their onsen, they have indoor and outdoor. Nice experience.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed here for a few nights during a work trip, the hotel was as expected in Tokyo, small room and tiny bathroom, but serviceable. The main issue was the follow-up. I left my watch in the room and the hotel has refused to be of any service. I appreciate it is my fault, but the inflexibility to help me recover an expensive item has been very frustrating. I wish the hotel had been more flexible to help their guest above and beyond a standard room.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I have stayed twice here in 2018 and have a booking again in Dec 22/23 to January 5 2019 this year.Clean, excellent staff and good location.Its near the station and many other good cafes.You will enjoy it here!!Peter- san

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: This hotel, for its price, is absolutely great. Located very close to the subway, it's two stops from Shinjuku station. If you come from Narita Airport and stop at Shinjuku, just take the Oedo line (e-27) and reach e-29. Use exit 1 and in not even 5 minutes walk you reach the hotel. The same metro station is a good point to reach other locations, but some require a change of line, eg if you want to go to Shibuya. If not confident, it is possible to catch a bus just 5 min walk from the hotel. Fantastic.The hotel is very nice, elegant and has all services you need: wifi free, laundry, SPAs, pools, you name it.Rooms are small, but had the essential. The bed was big, lights everywhere, massive tv screen with hotel information, bathroom with the typical Japanese toilet-bide with buttons. Very cool for one person.Rooms were clean and you could request eco-cleaning, meaning cleaners would only clean parts of your room to sustain the environment, and in exchange leave a bottle of water. Great if you only sleep in the hotel, and you want a drink to carry with you while exploring the city.If you add to your stay the breakfast, you will have available a buffet western style in the adjacent Irish Pub, which in the morning plays relaxing classical music, and from lunch typical western songs, and airing soccer matches too. Great atmosphere.There are a few issues:- staff is very nice and polite, but struggle a bit with English language. Just try your best and use Google Translate for further aid and you will be fine- the room I had was small like most in the Japan, but my wall was scratched. I told the receptionist and they solved the issue right away. - only 3 washing machines and 3 dryers are available, which means you will be waiting a lot, if you need to wash and dry your clothes.Overall, worth staying there, clearly recommended.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: It's situated out of hustle & bustle city. There are 2 entrances to subway station nearby the hotel. One is located right opposite the hotel and another is by lift about 3min walk along the hotel side.We had 4 days continuous stays there. Cleanliness is perfect. They replenish daily consumable and house keeping items although we put a note that we have enough :) (They will leave it in front of the room daily)There are post office, pharmacies, convenience stores and local fast food chain & McD, medium range restaurants nearby the hotel. However, there is no famous tourism spot within 1km. We explore an 1km+ night walk through a garden to the Metropolitan Building observation room. It's totally safe, as there are youngsters and skateboarders hang around there. Note: They allow early storage of luggage before check-in time.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed here for 4 nights as we were recommended to stay in Shinjuku area. This was a little way out (20min walk to Shinjuku station) however the nishinjuku subway stop was just outside the hotel.Check in was simple with the machines and that's the only time we spoke to anyone on the front desk. We were on the 2nd floor and it was slightly annoying that there were no available stairs so we had to keep getting the lift but there are 4 so it's not too inconvenientThe room was small but to be expected in Tokyo. There is only access to the double bed from one side. You can store your luggage under the bed so it's not an issue. However everything has its place and it had all the facilities you would expect. The bathroom was small but an excellent shower, hot and powerful which is always good. The worst part of the room were the pillows. Just one thin one each which was like foam and not comfortable at all. The rest of the bed was very comfortableOverall a decent place to stay in Tokyo for a reasonable price

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Why the pillows in the rooms are so uncomfortable...? I would have given a high score if the pillow would have been reasonable...Other then that, the hotel looks very nice, simple, but very nice and functional. The restaurant on the first floor is o.k, service not so...

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I booked this hotel in March, and when I emailed about my late arrival they never replied. Then, I called the hotel just before leaving home. The clerk spoke horrid English, and finally put someone on who spoke a bit better and who then answered my emails, assuring me all was well. I later wrote from Seoul two days before leaving reminding of my late arrival. Received assuring email. Then, the day before I left received a request for my arrival time, threatening to cancel room. I wondered if this was the Twilight Zone. I contacted Hotels.com via Twitter and they interceded, and was then assured the room would be there. Good, considering it was 11 p.m. before I finally arrived. When I got there, I was told I had to input info on computer instead of normal check-in. I protested as I was exhausted and insisted they had to help. Only one spoke passable English. All the others hardly any, and this infuriated me, as it's outrageous that a big hotel in Tokyo wouldn't have employees to do so. Many foreigners in the hotel spoke English. The man helped me to my room, which was, unlike the other Asian hotels, ridiculously small. No drawers except in desk. I had to put my suitcase at the end of the large bed and it was difficult to move in the tiny quarters reaching for clothes. The bathroom was small, requiring an unsafe step up, about 9 inches, where one could trip in the dark. The bathtub was small but deep, requiring huge step into in order to shower. The sink was too close to tub, squeezed between the toilet, with little room. But with all the failings, the toilet had a bidet! Plus, a huge TV, with only one English channel. BBC, At one point, the phone rang, and someone informed me they wanted to change the sheets, asking when I would leave the room (it was 12:45 p.m. and I'd just showered after a long night out, having awoken late). I told her I'd be out at 1:30, and she wanted me to leave earlier, so I just hung up on her. How dare her insist that I leave my room? It's not as if it was 5 p.m. or so when the staff was going home.When leaving the hotel, I had little help getting a cab to the Shinjuku train station to take the Narita Express to the Airport. No one understood such a common transport that many no doubt took to the airport so far away. They kept thinking I wanted a cab to the airport. It was baffling trying to communicate with them at an otherwise modern looking hotel, offering a pool (in season) and free Japanese baths for the guests (I didn't partake). I was so frustrated, it being the last day of my 40-day trip and I finally raised my voice to get their attention. Again, we are talking about a mode of transport that should be familiar to them.Plus, they made me go to the street alone to hail a cab (phone cabs charge $4 just to get there), and I easily got one, but he spoke no English and didn't understand what I was saying. I managed to get one of the clerks to come out and speak with the driver, but it was maddening how they kept misunderstanding where I was going, and at one point she told me I would have to go to an area at Shinjuku Station, which I knew from my experience there was mistaken. Finally, the driver (who also must have taken zillions of passengers to this common drop-off place) understood, but how is it possible that the hotel staff would not be familiar with how to get to a major nearby train station to catch the famous Narita Express? For this reason, though superficially from the outside it looks like a nice, modern hotel and after all this time of searching it DID have coin laundry machines, because of the poor service, the tiny rooms and the very sleepy neighborhood with apartments and offices, albeit with a nearby subway only two stops from Shinjuku and not far from other sites, I have to rate the hotel low.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I’m here for a business trip. The worse service I ever exerienced in a 4*. Very young and very inexpert staff. When I arrived they had issues on my booking and asked me waiting for very long time uselessly. One day later they had issues on payments, blocked my bedroom door key and keeped me waiting once again for a very very long time on nightime on my way back from a business day. I asked to speak with responsible: also him was a very young guy and was more worried about doing nothing than solving my issue. All my staff was in my room locked: incredible! Consider also that rooms are almost 3x3 meters (bathroom included) without any wardrobe. To complete, they will try each day to do not change you the towels and to do not restore the bed.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel is located just a short walk away from Nishi-Shinjuku Station. My family and I booked two rooms (8th floor) and stayed at this hotel for three nights.Couple of points for travellers to note:1) Check-in to this hotel is strictly 3pm! Not a minute before hand so if you plan on coming into see whether you can get a room earlier, that isn't going to happen. But the hotel is happy to keep your bags for you whilst you wander elsewhere. You can pay extra to get the room a couple of hours before hand (1,000 yen per hour).2) Public bath on Level 2 was great! Evenings are normally packed so I would recommend coming either in the morning (7-9am) or in the afternoon (at around 3pm whilst everything else is checking in). You have to bring your own towels.3) The Video on Demand which cost 1,000 yen provides you access to all the video channels for 24 hours. Although the instructions are not clear on the timing, I found out through experience!4) Lawsons and Family Mart are literally opposite the hotel so you definitely won't go hungry in the middle of the night.Finally, the rooms are on the smaller side. If you are travelling with two big bags than you will not have any floor space to walk. However, the room does have space underneath the bed that you can slide your bags to which will free up some space. But this gives you an idea.Otherwise, the room is comfortable and clean. Will definitely visit the hotel again if we are in the area.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel is just a minute walk to the station making it very accessible. There's automated check-in and stand by support staff in case of need of help. The bed size was just right and comfy.The room was however a smoking one so that was a little uncomfortable.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The hotel is really nice, the rooms are small like every other room we saw in Japan, but clean and comfortable.There's a metro station just around the corner, seven-eleven and family mart (very famous convenient shops in Japan) right across the street.There's an outdoor small pool, but tattooed people are not allowed in there! lol so we passed! But Japanese are not really big fans of tattoos in the first place..

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Loved it! Though the room was a bit small, the little details that the staff and builders put into the place really make a difference. When we arrived, our bath robes were neatly folded on our bed with a paper crane that topped both of them. The room was clean and the onsen was very nicely structured and tidy as well. I think the best little thing that I won't ever forget is the fact that a portion of the mirror above the sink in the bathroom is heated so it won't get steamed over when you shower. This makes such a difference and I love this small detail. Wifi is free and they also help with luggage storage as well if you need it. Would definitely stay here again in the near future when I come back. It's literally right outside the subway station exit.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed recently. Other than Hot Tub heater not working, hotel stay was great. Staff was very friendly and helpful. We had a great stay at this hotel, which is a few steps from the subway line and only two stops from Shinjuku Central Station.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: For a large hotel advertised to travels you should write on booking web sites pool and spa not friendly for tattooed people, I understand the view on tattoos in Japan but for a considerably large hotel advertised to travelers. It's unreasonable and discrimination.. I wouldn't have stayed at hotel if this was stated before check in.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: The SPA department was nice, and overall clean and nice. On "paper" location looked good, but for us 4 it was better to use taxi than metro, given the location of the E-subway. That being said, Shinjuku is only a few minutes and yen away!Pillows were no good, and the room was tiny, even for Japanese standards. The good thing here, was that we were able to store the suitcases underneath the bed (compared to another APA hotel, where this was not an option. We chose this hotel for our last two nights because of the swimming pool. We did not know, however, that this was an additional cost of 1000 yen per person, for every single use. This should be included.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: My husband and I stayed here for 6 nights in the height of summer. Having read reviews of the small rooms, small double beds and uncomfortable pillows, we booked a twin room, brought our own pillows, and shared one suitcase. The room was indeed small, but super clean. The single beds were large and very comfy, and linen very new. The bathroom was minuscule but very clean with a great shower. We had a room on level 20 with a view which we had requested and made a big difference given the room size. The air conditioning was super cold - great in the very hot weather. The TV was oversized for such a small room - only 1 English channel but that was fine. The highlights were the onsite Onsen, which we used twice a day to bath and was spotless and so relaxing, and the location. 1 Minute walk from the Oedo line, which connects to everywhere. And the area. Lots of inexpensive and delicious restaurants. Turn right out the door of the hotel for a hip coffee joint called "Counterpart" - another 1 min walk. We didn't have the onsite breakfast or go to the bar. The check in and out were speedy and everything else was so seamless that we didn't need to contact the staff.Very good wifi in the rooms and lobby. Highly recommended in this price bracket. We would stay there again in a heartbeat.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We were to apa hotel for 1 week and was really nice experience for our holiday in Tokyo...strategic position exactly in front of the station so very easy take train.The staff is professional and the hotel very clean , the only worse things of this hotel is the Irish Pub "Peter Cole" restaurant down stairs , around 12 clock i decided to have lunch with my wife before go to airport but when we sit the waitress come to us with very bad attitude and tell us you cant seat if you dont order food .. how can i order if u dont give me menù ..Im a chef and restaurant owner and i know very well about hospitality and trust me the service in this pub put down all quality of hotel .

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Spent two weeks here visiting family in Tokyo. One of the attractions for us was the nice pool in the height of summer. The heat was so bad the authorities called it a national disaster. People were dying. The locals were suffering, acknowledging it was unbearable. The answer? A nice swim would help. The problem? A 1000 yen $13AUD for an maximum hour swim per swimmer. Yep, this great pool sat empty most of the time because of the excessive fees to use it. We have stayed in hotels in many countries and have always had use of the pool as part of our payment.For those who tried to swim for free there was a camera at the pool and a staff member would come scuttling up from the office with a clipboard, and actually make the swimmer sign for payment whilst in the pool. Don't stay APA if you want to use the amenities as part of your stay like normal hotels.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Stayed here for four nights. Clean, but super small rooms, so you have to have The luggage under The bed in order to move around. We got a room with a really nice city view, even though we hadn’t payed for it. Close to the main Shinjuku area, 2k walk or 2 stops on the metro. The station is just outside The hotel, which is very convenient. The pool is nice, but a little small. Only six sun beds, but not that many seemed to use it either, so we did not have any problems getting sun beds.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: We stayed there at the APA hotel in July 2018. It's located within a mess than 5 minute walk from a train station and has a spa onsite which was awesome as we hit Tokyo during an unprecedented heat wave. We were traveling with our 20 year old son and our exchange student, both loved the hotel. The rooms are incredibly small, but the AC is downright icy and few rooms are big in Tokyo anyway.Down the street are a couple of restaurants, but the closeness of the train station is one of the biggest pluses.Highly recommend!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I love everything about the hote! We stayed 3 nights and I did not encounter any problem during the whole stay. It is our first time in Japan and I did not regret booking at this hotel. Exterior and interior design of the property are very well presented. Location was just 2mins walk to the train station. Checking in and out are very efficient and digitalized. But take note that it’s a self service hotel so no one will take care of your luggages. Room are small but I dont mind it as I have everything on hand. Room amenities are always refilled and cleaned. Breakfast was great and staff are considerate to even accept us one time when we came late and let us get our food quickly as they are closing.Unfortunately, we weren’t able to try their pool and man made hotspring but they looked attractive!The TV channels are all in Japan langauage so it was useless for us. But doesnt matter as we use our laptop /ipad to entertain my 6 year old son.Hotel rates are very reasonable with above service standard!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I read reviews about how small this place was, that rooms were not big enough and so on. First of all I booked my hotel for 3 nights the day before, I heard that when coming to Tokyo that you should book in advance since places are always sold out. This was not the case for me, not only were rooms available, they were the cheapest I found. The location is amazing, there is literally a subway station across the street, making my commute to the city super easy and fast. Rooms are small but efficient. I came alone and really all I needed was a room to sleep in and shower, I wasn't here for the pool or hanging out in my room.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: After 3 weeks in China, I arrived in Tokyo and at my hotel at 10pm. I was ready for some downtown. The building is conveniently located across from E29 stop. Major points scored here for location. The self check-in process was new to me. The front desk person was helpful through this process. I booked a semi-double room for 1 week. I was on the 20th floor the top floor of the tower. I was prepared for small but was shocked at the size in person, initially. I’m from NYC, and we have small spaces but this is on another level. I was tired so went straight to bed.I woke up the morning and headed for breakfast on the lobby floor. Traditional English breakfast everyday. It was a nice little break from eating Japanese and Chinese food for 4 weeks. Although very yummy Japanese food is. When you go down, do t forget the paper slip that shows you’re breakfast voucher.Overall, the hotel is nice. It’s clean. And it gets the job done in the most efficient way possible. I even come to appreciate the little space in the room. I would stay in another APA. Thanks for a restful stay.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Design of the hotel: beautiful and logical. Room is small but very clean and acceptable price. Auto checkin/checkout and quickly. Helpful staff. Located very close to nishi shinjukugochome station, just one minute walking. It takes 2 hours from Narita airport by limousine bus and nearly 1.30 hour by Narita express train. Many minmarts and small rétaurants are near the hotel. Clinic as well. Please don’t mistake between shinjuku station ( a big center station) and nishi shinjukugochome. When searching on google map, it will make you confused.

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: If you’re looking for a place to stay close to a subway station this is the place! It’s clean, cheap and with a really good service. English breakfast buffet is available for ¥1500 in advanced per person. Rooms are clean and cozy and the amenities provided are awesome. Too bad you have to pay for the swimming pool ¥1000... English is spoken but not that good by all staff members

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Awesome hotel with really good facilities. Close to subway - Oedo line takes you to mist places. Onsen and pool are a bonus. Helpful staff and new and clean hotel. Rooms are as per Tokyo standards. Many convenience stores close by. Walking distance to the park and Tokyo government building

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I really recommend this place as long as your stay there will be a very quiet, clean and comfy.They have a kind of onsen place on second floor and there is an option of self-laundry. Check as well if you would like to have smoking or non smoking room.They have a buffet breakfast for additional price, which is quite affordable.To get there from Narita airport its easy as well. Just take a bus till Keio Shinjuku, and from there either via metro either via taxi you can get til Nishishinjuku station. It’s exactly 5 minutes walking distance till hotel. On the street close by there is few grocery stores and cafés .Fantastic location!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: Booked for a 4 night city break while backpacking Asia and found this please to be amazing quality for a 3 star hotel for it's cost.Travelling on a budget we of course picked the small double room and we were prepared for it to be small in advance but is was very clean and had everything we needed and more and the use of space is fantastic!We were disappointed the pool was closed so we were not able to use it due to the time of year (end of June) and the only negative about the room was the inconvenience of having to climb over your partner in the night to be able to get out of bed for a wee...Would stay again and have to say give the Japanese bath a go at least once during your visit!

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I booked a single room for 5 nights in this hotel while on a holiday with my family) they were at the Hyatt Regency, about 10 mins away). I have stayed in APA in Kyoto twice, and this was the better of the two APA hotels. Pros: Single room felt larger than the single room I had in Kyoto.Good location – mere minutes from the subway (be sure to locate the lift if you have heavy suitcases), and two convenience stores just across the road. There’s a drug store that opens late into the night.In-house onsen – the Japanese spa on the second floor was a godsend after a long day. Not terribly authentic but adequate for my needs. I skipped the claustrophobic shower and had my wash in the onsen instead. Perfect!Automated check-in counter – the APA in Kyoto did not have it. It’s very useful given the staff’s English skills were only so-so. When checking out, I simply inserted my key card and that was it. Great idea. Tip: Pay cash to save on the exchange rate.Wifi – worked like a charm.Irish bar on the ground floor – I had arrived on the night Japan beat Colombia. I managed to catch bits of the action. The mood was fantastic! I did not have breakfast here so I can’t comment.Automated laundry – very convenient when you’ve been on the road for a while.Shinjuku-chio park about 5 minutes away. It’s small, but nice for a quick run (I ended doing a 10km, exploring Shinjuku). There’s a small shrine inside the park – pop in for a look! Cons: The pillow was utter CRAP (apparently several TripAdvisor reviewers share my sentiment) – I ended up using my travel pillow. The management really need to do something about this.Staff’s English skills are weak – if you need a lot of help with booking stuff/getting around, you may be frustrated.Pool – it’s tiny so you are looking to do laps, go elsewhere.No gym (but then again, most local hotel chains won’t have a gym). Bottom line: If you don't plan to spend a lot of time in your room, it's a top choice for single travellers. Just be prepared for the crappy pillow :)

hotel_name: APA Hotel & Resort Nishishinjuku Gochome-eki Tower
review_body: I rate this hotel 3-star. Having said that they score high on practically all counts. The hotel is newly upgraded and that is clearly visible. The lobby area offers nothing in particular but offers an airy, welcoming feeling.
